        <td id="LC33" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">##</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>Specific Conductance and pH</span></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L34" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="34"></td>
        <td id="LC34" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L35" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="35"></td>
        <td id="LC35" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mi">*pH*</span> is a measure of the acidity of water. Most natural rivers have pH close to 7 (neutral), but depending on the geology of the watershed they drain, pH can be higher or lower. Most aquatic life has difficulty living in pH less than 6. In areas high in limestone, such as much of the southern Appalachian mountain range, pH tends to be between 7.5 and 8. </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L36" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="36"></td>
        <td id="LC36" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L37" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="37"></td>
        <td id="LC37" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mi">*Specific conductance*</span> is a measure of water&#39;s ability to conduct electricity. Because conductivity depends on the number of ions in solution, specific conductance is an inexpensive estimate of how many salts are in solution. Specific conductance is dependant on the <span class="pl-mi">_total_</span> ionic strength of the water, and cannot be directly converted to concentrations of any one ion. In general though, saltier water will have higher specific conductance. Units for specific conductance in freshwater are microsiemens per centimeter at 25<span class="pl-c1">&amp;deg;</span>C.</td>
      </tr>

        <td id="L38" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="38"></td>
